message.content:
1. Verb tenses are used in language to express time relationships between the verb and other elements within a sentence, such as subjects or objects. There are several main categories of verb tenses, which can be further divided into simple, progressive, perfect, and compound forms:

2. Simple Tenses:
a. Present Tense: Indicates an action happening now or a habitual action. Example: "I eat lunch at noon."
b. Past Tense: Indicates an action that occurred in the past. Example: "She finished her homework last night."
c. Future Tense: Indicates an action that will happen in the future. Example: "They are going to visit Paris next summer."

3. Progressive (Continuous) Tenses:
a. Present Progressive Tense: Indicates an ongoing action or situation at the moment of speaking. Example: "I am reading a book."
b. Past Progressive Tense: Indicates an ongoing action in the past, often used with other past actions. Example: "She was writing a letter when the phone rang."
c. Future Progressive Tense: Indicates an ongoing action that will happen in the future. Example: "They will be traveling to Europe next month."

4. Perfect Tenses:
a. Present Perfect Tense: Indicates an action completed at an unspecified time before now or a connection between past and present. Example: "He has finished his project."
b. Past Perfect Tense: Indicates an action completed before another past action. Example: "She had eaten dinner when I arrived."
c. Future Perfect Tense: Indicates an action that will be completed at some point in the future before another future event occurs. Example: "By next year, they will have built a new school."

5. Compound Tenses (Combination of tense and aspect):
a. Present Continuous Perfect Tense: Combines present continuous and present perfect aspects, indicating an ongoing action that started in the past and continues into the present. Example: "I am having lunch with my friend right now."
b. Past Continuous Perfect Tense: Combines past continuous and past perfect aspects, indicating an ongoing action in the past that was interrupted or completed by another past event. Example: "She was writing a letter when she realized it was too late to mail it."
c. Future Continuous Perfect Tense: Combines future continuous and future perfect aspects, indicating an ongoing action that will continue into the future and be completed at some point before another future event. Example: "By next week, they will have been building the house for a month."

These tenses help convey various time relationships and nuances in language, making communication more precise and effective.
